title: Chuck Schumer
deleted: In 2017, Schumer wrote to President Trump advocating for a block on China that would prevent the latter country from purchasing more American companies to increase pressure on Beijing to help rein in the nuclear missile program of North Korea.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/13/trump-china-national-security-242676|title=Trump blocks Chinese purchase of U.S. company for national security reasons|date=September 13, 2017|work=Politico|author=Cassella, Megan|access-date=September 20, 2020}}</ref> In May 2018, after President Trump signaled his willingness to ease sanctions on [[ZTE]] in a bid for a trade deal with Beijing, Schumer observed, "This seems to be an area where Democrats and Republicans in the House and the Senate are coming together and telling the president, you've got to be tough on China, you have to have your actions match your rhetoric."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/05/22/china-zte-rollback-sanctions-trump-563809|title=Lawmakers from both parties unite against Trump's ZTE sanctions rollback|date=May 22, 2018|work=[[Politico]]|author=Behsudi, Adam|access-date=September 20, 2020}}</ref>

title: Chuck Schumer
deleted: Schumer became the first senator to call for U.S. support for [[Kurdish independence]] following the results of the [[2017 Kurdistan Region independence referendum]], releasing a resolution calling for the U.S. government to change its policy to "support a political process that addresses the aspirations of the Kurds for an independent state". He called upon [[Iraq]] to "engage in a dialogue and peacefully determine the best way to accommodate the well-deserved and legitimate aspirations of the Iraqi Kurds".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/us-senate-democratic-leader-declares-support-for-kurdish-independence-1.662245|title=US Senate Democratic leader declares support for Kurdish independence|work=The National|author=Joyce Karam|date=28 September 2017}}</ref>

title: Chuck Schumer
added: Schumer was the chairman of the [[Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee]], part of the Democratic senate leadership, with primary responsibility for raising funds and recruiting Democratic candidates in the [[United States general elections, 2006|2006 Senate election]]. When he took this post, he announced that he would not run for [[Governor of New York]] in [[New York gubernatorial election, 2006|2006]], as many had speculated he would. This step avoided a potentially divisive gubernatorial [[primary election]] in 2006 between Schumer and [[Eliot Spitzer]], then New York's [[attorney general]].

While chairman in 2006, staffers of the committee obtained a copy of Maryland's 2006 Republican senate candidate [[Michael Steele]]'s [[credit report]]. A staff researcher used Steele's social security number to obtain his credit report from [[TransUnion]]. The report was paid for with the DSCC credit card issued to the researcher's supervisor. After an internal investigation, the Maryland Democratic Party determined the credit report was obtained illegally and reported the incident to the [[U.S. Attorney]].<ref>{{cite news

| access-date = September 18, 2006 }}</ref> The staffer resigned and pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of computer fraud and was sentenced to 150 hours of community service.<ref name=dscc2>{{cite news|last1=Wagner|first1=John|title=Democrat Pleads Guilty in Steele Case|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/03/24/AR2006032401726.html|access-date=January 8, 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=March 25, 2006}}</ref> The supervisor resigned from the DSCC.<ref name=dscc1>{{cite news

Under Schumer, in the 2006 elections, the Democratic Party gained six seats in the senate, defeating incumbents in each of those races and regaining control of the senate for the first time since 2002. Of the closely contested races in the Senate in 2006, the Democratic Party lost only [[Tennessee]]. The incoming [[Senate Majority Leader]], Harry Reid, persuaded Schumer to continue to serve another term as DSCC chair.
In 2009, for the [[111th Congress]], Schumer was succeeded as the DSCC chair by senator [[Bob Menendez]] of New Jersey.

The [[Democratic Caucus of the United States Senate|Senate Democratic caucus]] elected Schumer [[Minority Leader of the United States Senate|minority leader]] in November 2016. Schumer had been widely expected to lead Senate Democrats following the 2015 retirement announcement of his predecessor, Harry Reid. He is the first New Yorker, as well as the first [[Jews|Jewish person]], to serve as a Senate leader.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2016/11/16/chuck-schumer-elected-succeed-harry-reid-senate-minority-leader/D4284OThDQcJfsrR5XkWoK/story.html|title=Democrats shake up Senate leadership|last1=O'Keefe|first1=Ed|date=November 16, 2016|last2=DeBonis|first2=Mike|newspaper=The Boston Globe|access-date=November 22, 2016}}</ref> On January 20, 2021, Democrats gained a majority in the U.S. Senate with the swearing-in of newly-elected Georgia senators [[Jon Ossoff]] and [[Raphael Warnock]], making Schumer the majority leader, replacing Republican Mitch McConnell of Kentucky.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/524322-schumer-becomes-new-senate-majority-leader|newspaper=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|title=Schumer becomes new Senate majority leader|author=Bolton, Alexander|date=January 20, 2021|access-date=January 20, 2021|archive-date=January 21, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210121055723/https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/524322-schumer-becomes-new-senate-majority-leader}}</ref>
